newsitem.title: USA: Laboratory Corp settles test claims - U.S. Justice.
newsitem.headline: Laboratory Corp settles test claims - U.S. Justice.

text.p: Laboratory Corp. of America agreed to pay $182 million to settle civil allegations that it submitted false claims for unnecessary tests to federal and state health-care programs, the U.S. Justice Department said Thursday.

In addition, it said a Laboratory Corp. subsidiary pleaded guilty in North Carolina to submitting a false claim for an unnecessary blood test to the federal Medicare program and the California Medicaid program. The unit was fined $5 million.
The Justice Department said the settlement was the largest ever reached between the government and a clinical laboratory.
The settlement was announced by the U.S. attorney in North Carolina in a statement and at a news conference there. The Justice Department made available a copy of his news release.

According to the criminal charges, Laboratory Corp.'s Allied Clinical Laboratories in San Diego would add a high-density lipoprotein cholesterol test to a battery of procedures requested by a doctor, even though the cholesterol test was unneeded for the patient's treatment or diagnosis.
The Justice Departrment said the company then billed the federal and state governments for the cholesterol tests, knowing they were unnecessary.
In the civil case, the federal government alleged that Laboratory Corp submitted false claims for cholesterol and other "add-on" tests, knowing they were unneeded for the treatment of the patients.
"Often, doctors were led to believe that there would be little or no additional cost for the extra tests or that they had no choice regarding ordering options," a department official said.
The government said the doctors were unaware that the labs would bill federal or state insurance programs a separate amount for the extra tests.

June Gibbs Brown, inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services, said in a statement the agreement was the third-largest financial settlement involving health-care fraud in the history of the false-claims law.
